against the proposition.

comments.author: sean cuff

comments.text:
yes. I understand that.

but not because of acidity or lack of oxygen.

that's all i'm saying. 

somehow, I feel like i'm being antagonized for questioning things.
comments.author: adamklam1

comments.text:
Well, apparently the bogs of northern Europe pose enough of a problem to 
most bacteria.
comments.author: lasschesteven

comments.text:
I didn't forget that. o_o`
that's exactly what im saying I think is wrong.
skin, has unique connectivity between cells that give it elasticity, and 
the dead dry outer layers thats like a protective coating sort of.. but it 
decomposes by jsut about the same processes as the rest of the flesh.

highly acidic and oxygen free aren't a problem for alot of bacteria. . i 
just proposed an experiment for you if you'd like to test that. u can 
replace leaves for a small animal and achieve the same result, though, 
should only take a bit longer... i proposed composting leavesbecause it is 
a bit more practical.

if it was permafrost conditions that would make alot of sense, but then i'd 
attribute the preservation more to it being cold.

U'd be amazed how varied and robust bacteria can be. some bacteria produce 
their own antifreeze to continue operation in cold climates, othershave 
mechanisms to keep their membranes highly selective to keep their inards 
highly separated from their enviroments and create little bubbles with 
microenviroments within themselves to carry out certain metabolic 
processes. 

there are plenty of ways that bacteria and archeans circumvent conventional 
ideas about what is needed to live.
comments.author: adamklam1

comments.text:
You're forgetting the highly acidic and almost oxygen-free bog environment, 
and the fact that the bacteria would first have to eat their way through 
the skin before getting to the innards. It's not like they dumped nicely 
chopped up corpses in there.
comments.author: lasschesteven

comments.text:
well i say slowest. but not 4000 years slow.
I'd like to think my understanding was fairly good since i studied 
microbiology as one of my majors.
u can experiment with this when u make compost. if u fill a trash bin with 
leaves & some water and then top if with a layer of mineral oil cover it 
and put it somewhere cool - if ur in a nothern-isn country it'll take 
something like a year or  two to decompose most of the way through. but if 
u put it in a composting bin and turn it biweekly, ull have great compost 
in only a few months.(PS if u try the anaerobic method, be careful when u 
finally open up the container- as the H2S is overwhelmingly stinky. I did 
this myself in an attempt to evolve methane gas but the stink of H2S really 
makes u wana vomit, its like.. fart smell.. but quite literally 100x 
concentrated)

I would expect maybe something like a particular situation perhaps through 
an inorganic process converting the fermentation products (alcohols) into 
aldehydes which arrest further microbial activity?? maybe?...i have some 
other theories, which are probably wrong. but i am just about certain that 
even in cold climates, in anaerobic acidic conditions there are plenty of 
things that could continue to break down dead matter.
comments.author: adamklam1

comments.text:

'survive' in the bog for a couple thousand years.

those rot meat.... the H2S generated in swamps and septic tanks come from

I think he may have missed the mark just a bit by saying that the bacteria

circumstances which have arrested the microbial activity that would have 
rotted the corpse. -- and while acidity and lack of oxygen leaves only the

of varieties of microbes that can do that.

top_comment.author: QuikVidGuy

comments.text:
+QuikVidGuy  Prehistory ends much earlier in places with writing. So for 
example, you could argue prehistory ends in the Middle-East with the advent 
of cuneiform around 3000BC but in Europe it continues up until the Roman 
conquest, or atleast till Greeks start writing about us. In Oceania for 
example prehistory holds until the european colonisation period despite 
Oceanic cultures having some of the longest and most unbroken oral 
histories, like the aboriginals who were pretty much telling the same 
stories and distilling the same culture for ten thousand years (really an 
example of colonial bias still prevailing in history and archeology :/ ) 
But yes as the other fella says its a very loose term amongst academics. 
(Plus theres some evidence i the danube of pre sumerian writing forms so 
we'll see what the future holds.)

comments.author: IPushButtonsChannel

comments.text:
Stone Age, Iron Age, Bronze Age etc. are just technological and social 
classifications. They came at different times in different places. Because 
of a variety of mostly environmental factors the north of Europe advanced 
to the Iron Age much much later than say, the Egyptians. Also, prehistoric 
just means "before we have written history". Since writing wasn't a feature 
of Iron Age Northern Europe, largely for cultural reasons, it's prehistoric.

Hope that helps :)

top_comment.text:
Anyone here who is willing to explain to me the difference between a bog 
and a marsh? I think this is the first time I heard the word "bog".﻿
top_comment.author: Emanuel May

comments.text:
+Emanuel May
Mosses and, often, carnivorous plants. They tend to grow heather when 
they're drained.
comments.author: TRiG (Ireland)

comments.text:
+Nillie I don't know why your comment was tagged as spam, but I restored it.

Yeah I have tried reading in wikipedia first, but as a non-native speaker 
it is sometimes easier to let people explain it than to read articles with 
many technical terms I don't know.

So (generally speaking) a swamp is wetland with high growing plants and 
trees, a marsh is wetland with smaller sized plants like bushes and shrubs 
and bogs have not much of a vegetation except mosses?

In my native language we have only two terms to differentiate wetlands 
(swamps and marshes), so 'bogs' were completely new to me :) Thank you, too!
comments.author: Emanuel May

comments.text:
+AislingLauraLand So 'bog' is mainly a regional word? That explains why 
it's new to me :) Thanks for the info!
comments.author: Emanuel May

comments.text:
Bog comes from the Gaelic word 'Bogach' meaning marsh/peatland in English 
so I guess there's not a huge difference, marshes are generally wetter then 
bogs though?
comments.author: AislingLauraLand

comments.text:
A marsh is dominated by grasses, rushes or reeds, while bogs are formed 
from the accumulation of peat mosses.

comments.text:
+Tom Henryk Ignoring these other guys, the term SHC comes from accounts as 
early as the 1800's and these deaths were a person buning to death and 
there was little evidence of a flame source so people, being the 1800"s, 
aautomatically said it was spontaneous combustion of a human. More recently 
people leave out crucial facts about the surroundings when telling stories 
about it, like the person was smoking or that there was a heater nearby, so 
everyone thinks its spontaneous and the term SHC lives on.
comments.author: Brandon R

comments.text:

Regarding Spontaneous Combustions non-existence... (why you and that other

comments.text: +Daniel Rowley Amazing! Thank you for the information.
comments.author: Thomas Sulkoske

comments.text:
I saw a documentary awhile ago. I'll try to find it but it was fascinating. 
the Gist is that the Idea of SHC came from Fire inspectors in the 20's 
traced some fires to entirely recognizable corpses. This meant they 
appeared to be roasted from the inside out, quickly. This was wrongfully 
described as the "spontaneous combustion of a human". People got the wrong 
idea of what was happening. 

The reason corpses in certain fires look like a whole roasted pig, is 
caused by "the Human wick effect" which is when a fire is hot enough to 
render the fat from under your skin and set it on fire. The Human is 
combusting quickly, sustaining the flame too. But the fire is always from a 
foreign source.

captions.text:
On May 6, 1950, two Danish brothers digging
for peat in a local bog unearthed a murder
victim.

Based on the condition of the body, they figured
the crime had happened recently, so they called

the police. But there was nothing the authorities
could do because the man’s murders — and

the man — had both died like 2200 years
ago.

Today he’s known as Tollund Man, and thanks
to the amazing chemistry of bogs, this naturally

mummified person from the Iron Age is considered
one of the best preserved prehistoric bodies
in the world.

Bogs are found throughout the world, but the
low-oxygen, highly-acidic bogs of northern

Europe have proven to be ideal for preserving
ancient humans, animals, and even butter.

For more than 150 years, hundreds of bog bodies
have been uncovered in Denmark, Ireland, Germany

and the Netherlands -- many of which still
have their internal organs intact.

Tollund Man may be the best preserved of them,
but he’s far from the oldest. In 2011, a

peat farmer in Ireland unearthed a body dated
to about 4,000 years ago, making him the world’s
oldest human specimen with intact skin.

So how exactly do bogs do their preservation
magic?

Let’s start by looking at how they form,
over thousands of years: A bog begins with

lots of moss, particularly a type known as
Sphagnum, growing in wet, low-lying areas.

Sphagnum absorbs lots of nutrients from the
soil, especially ions of magnesium and calcium,

which make the soil highly acidic. And even
though there’s lots of water around, it

doesn’t circulate, which means there’s
no oxygen dissolving and flowing around.

That’s bad news for bacteria, which can’t
survive in an acidic, anaerobic environment.

And that means that nothing is around to break
down the dead moss and other vegetation. In
other words, decomposition can’t happen.

What’s left over time is undecomposed mush
that piles up, known as peat. Moss continues

to grow on top of those piles, and the layers
of peat accumulate. Bogs form when the peat

builds up faster than any decomposition can
occur.

In bog-rich countries, peat is often farmed
for use as soil conditioner, fuel, even animal

bedding. So ancient specimens in bogs are
generally found -- and sadly, often destroyed
-- by farm equipment.

Scientists are still learning about the chemical
processes that take place in those bogs over

hundreds and thousands of years. We know,
for example, that tannins produced by the

moss can be as acidic as vinegar -- which
can basically turn skin into leather.

But one of the strangest properties of bog
bodies is that, while skin, hair, and organs

may all be preserved, the acidic mixture often
dissolves calcium phosphate in the bones,
leaving a body without a skeleton.

pH levels vary from bog to bog, though, which
means some bodies may be more or less preserved
than others.

So here’s another question: What are those
bodies doing there in the first place?!

Archeologists think ancient Celtic tribes
used bogs for religious ceremonies, including

dedications and, yes, sacrifices. Some bodies
appear to have been tortured -- discovered

with nooses around their necks, others with
holes in their skulls. One body revealed entrails

partially pulled out through incisions. Some
archeologists have linked this kind of behavior
to Iron Age paganism.

Tollund Man was found with a leather noose
around his neck, and an autopsy revealed that

he died from hanging. While nearly everyone
who died in Denmark at that time was cremated,

it turns out that those who were sacrificed
were buried in bogs.

Finally, not all uses of ancient bogs were
so gruesome. Hundreds of large packages of

butter and lard have been discovered in bogs,
where they were buried to keep them from going
rancid.

The question is: would it still be good on
my toast? I’m waiting for science to answer
me that question, but in the meantime:

Thanks for watching this SciShow Dose -- especially
our Subbable subscribers. To learn how you

can support us, just go to Subbable.com/scishow.
If you have questions, you can find us on

Facebook and Twitter and as always in the
comments below, and if you want to keep getting

smarter with us, just go to YouTube.com/scishow
and subscribe!

title: Chemistry & Corpses: The Science of Bog Bodies
